content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It took me 3m46s to solve this problem. I believe this problem is quite approachable since you mostly have to implement the steps described in the problem. The visual aspect also makes it engaging.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is awesome! :)
I love fractals and Sierpinski triangles are one of the coolest.

I solved it in exactly 5 minutes (including reading time), so I think it's suitable for a clash.

The instructions are really great and make the problem much more approachable. The only thing I'd suggest is making it more clear that the characters used for the triangles differ from test to test - I didn't realise this at first.

Bro, you come up with the most creative challenges i see. And i hate denying em, but honestly this doesn’t seem too doable within the time limits. I’m not gonna deny this as maybe my POV is wrong, but i would maybe suggest decreasing N to <=3 or 4, in order to simplify the complex nature that comes from the recursive pattern and layout. Best of luck!

Are you sure this is doable within the clash time limit?

As you've already shown the first three triangles in the statement, players can copy and paste them directly in their solution.

Also, why are all tests the same as their corresponding validators?

Thanks.

I am quite sure it is doable within the clash time limit.

As for the tests, I think the 4th test will pose some problems to copy-pasters, but it's probably better to disallow copying altogether.

Was thinking of providing the 1st Sierpinski triangle instead and let players develop from there, for example:

<<Input>>
 *
* *
2 (N)

<<Output>>
   *
  * *
 *    *
* * * *

What do you think?

Thanks for the feedback, appreciate your honest reviews :)
My take is that, if you can solve N=3, then you can easily replicate that logic to N=4 or N=5.
Thanks for trying :) How would you suggest I change the phrasing to specify that the triangle is different from puzzle to puzzle?

I would add this at the end of the statement:
<<Note>>: The {{N=1}} triangle provided is different from test to test, using different characters and changing in size.

Then in Input I would change this line to say:
<<Next [[K]] lines:>> A string of length exactly [[2K]] - the {{N=1}} triangle for this test.

I can understand your point, i only suggested it as a a possible way to simplify the problem. At the end of the day, it’s your challenge. Do you have any possible ideas on how you could simplify it a bit? Or would you rather keep it as is

To me, the crux of this problem is the recursive construction algorithm. I have tried my best to define this algorithm explicitly through the provided example, but at the end of the day, I think it still boils down to the skill of the programmer to implement this algorithm. It is definitely a bit of a challenge to perform the required string manipulations, but I think it is doable.

After thinking it through, this does seem doable within the time limit. That said, having the tests and validators be identical makes hardcoding too easy. I agree the 4th test might catch some copy-pasters, but they'd still pass 3 out of 4, which undermines the goal. That’s why it’s important to keep tests and validators distinct, to discourage hardcoding and promote actual problem-solving.

As for both your current and revised ideas, there's a practical limit: once N > 4, the output size exceeds the maximum character limit. You'll need to rethink the output format so that you can differentiate tests and validators. One option could be to output only the first 1000 characters, though that might make the output visually less appealing.
I have re-worked the problem so that the starting triangle is different for each case. This allows me to keep the underlying logic of the puzzle while still being able to differentiate validators.

Goal/Input
Please change all instances of "{{N=}}" to "[[N]]=" (i.e. only the values should be formatted as constants).

Thanks.
